commit_message:
Self Management of Roles and Domain Scoped Roles

This specifies an API to allow federated users to self-register to
join domain based groups which can then be assigned to roles or domain based
roles in the normal way.

Change-Id: I1232c3dbcc6bcc4195ec3dd6e32c7a7cbc29c255
Co-authored-by: Ioram Sette <iss@cin.ufpe.br>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/72/142072/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Self Management of Roles and Domain Scoped Roles ================================================ This specifies a new API to allow federated users to self-register to join domain based groups, which can then be assigned to roles or domain scoped roles in the normal way. Problem Description =================== In a federation, both users and keystone/domain administrators may not know the identifiers or identity attributes that IdPs assert for their users. It is therefore difficult, if not impossible, for a keystone or domain administrator to add the correct mapping rules to Keystone in order to assign particular roles or domain scoped roles to particular federated users. Proposed Change =============== We propose to enable Keystone and/or domain administrators to manage the membership of roles and/or domain scoped roles within a federation, by inviting federated users to join a group, which is referred to them as a Virtual Organisation Role (VO Role). The administrator then assigns the group to the required role(s) or domain scoped role(s) in the usual way, so that the users get the appropriate privileges in OpenStack. The self management API automatically creates the correct mapping rule for each user to join a particular domain based group. In this way, each time a user authenticates to Keystone via his IdP, there will be the correct mapping rule in Keystone to place the user in the correct group, and from there, to be assigned to the correct role(s) or domain scoped role(s). Each group created by this specification is protected by a secret or PIN, which has to be quoted by the federated users who wish to join the group. Users refer to PIN-protected groups as Virtual Organisation Roles or VO Roles. PIN protected groups are assigned OpenStack roles and domain specific roles in the normal way, via assignments, so that all the members of a group (i.e. a VO role) have the same privileges. Alternatives ------------ There has to be a way for a federated user or Keystone administrator to find out which identity attributes and/or identifier the user's IdP asserts for the user, before the Keystone administrator can manually configure the correct mapping rule into Keystone. This places a large burden on either or both of the federated user and the Keystone administrator. Firstly, the identity attributes have to be determined, and secondly, the correct mapping rule has to be created. Even then, the user has no control over which groups he is a member of - he cannot see them or resign from them. So an alternative to the current proposal would need the following capabilities: a) a way of capturing the identity attributes that an IdP releases for a user - perhaps the audit logs could be used for this b) a way of creating the correct mapping rule - the current configuration method could be used c) a way of letting the user see what groups he is a member of - perhaps a new API for this d) a way of letting the user resign from the groups he does not want to be a member of - perhaps a new API for this. Data Model Impact ----------------- Three new relational tables are needed: i) A table to hold the definitions of the PIN protected groups (VO roles) ii) A table to hold the user requests to join a group (VO role) iii) A table to hold blacklisted users REST API Impact --------------- Admin API on VO Roles --------------------- Create a VO role. This creates a VO role (PIN protected group) and returns its details if successful. Required Attributes: - `VO_name` (string) The name of the domain (Virtual Organisation). - 'Role' (string) The name of the group (VO role). - `secret` (string) The secret to be presented by users to register for this VO role. Optional attributes: - `description` (string) Describes the VO role. If a value is not specified by the client, the service will default this value to`null`. - `enabled` (boolean) Indicates whether this VO role is active or not. If a value is not specified by the client, the service will default this to `true`. - `automatic_join` (boolean) Indicates if the domain administrator must enable user VO role memberships after their join requests. If a value is not specified by the client, the service will default this to `false`. URL: `PUT /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles` Request: { "VO_role": { "automatic_join": false, "description": "The Keystone developers", "enabled": true, "pin": "1234", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" } } Response: Status: 201 Created { "VO_role": { "automatic_join": false, "description": "The Keystone developers", "enabled": true, "id": "6e78fa", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/6e78fa" }, "pin": "1234", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" } } List VO roles. This lists all the VO roles in a domain (VO) URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_name}` Response: Status: 200 OK { "VO_roles": [ { "automatic_join": false, "description": "The Keystone developers", "enabled": true, "id": "6e78fa", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/6e78fa" }, "pin": "1234", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" }, { "automatic_join": false, "description": "The Keystone Implementors", "enabled": true, "id": "b345a2", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/b345a2" }, "pin": "9999", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "implementor" } ], } Get a VO role. This gets the details of a particular VO role. URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_role}/{VO_name}` URL: 'GET /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}' Response: Status: 200 OK { "VO_role": { "automatic_join": false, "description": "The Keystone Implementors", "enabled": true, "id": "b345a2", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/b345a2" }, "pin": "9999", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "implementor" } } Delete a VO role URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_role}/{VO_name}` URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}` Response: Status: 204 No Content Update VO role URL: `PATCH /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}` URL: `PATCH /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_role}/{VO_name}` Any of the following parameters can be updated: automatic_join, description, enabled, pin, VO_role. They take effect immediately. Updating the last parameter will cause a new VO role to be created, the role occupants to be copied across, then the original VO role will be deleted. Request: { "VO_role": { "enabled": false } } Response: Status: 200 OK { "VO_role": { "automatic_join": false, "description": "Keystone Developers", "enabled": false, "id": "6e78fa", "links": { "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/6e78fa" }, "pin": "1234", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" } } Admin API on VO role membership ------------------------------- Add a VO role member. This operation is called by the VO management code when either a user requests to join a VO role (automatic enrolment), or when the administrator accepts the user's request (non-automatic enrolment). This operation creates an attribute mapping rule for the identified user, based on the name of the IdP that performed the user authentication, and the unique user ID provided by the IdP, and adds this rule to the mapping rule for the IdP. The returned id is the id of the updated mapping rule. URL: `PUT /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/member` Request: { "member": { "idp": "kent.ac.uk", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer", "user_id": "dwc24" } } Response: Status: 200 OK { { "id": "34cb2d", "user_id": "dwc24", "idp": "kent.ac.uk" } } List all the members of a VO role. An administrator should be able to list the members of any VO role. Other users should only be granted access to member lists of the VO roles they are members of. Attempts to list the members of any other VO role should return HTTP status 403 Forbidden. URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}/members` URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_role}/{VO_name}/members` Response: Status: 200 OK { "members": [ { "id": "34cb2d", "user_id": "abc@idp", "idp": "64ef2a" }, { "id": "34cd2d", "user_id": "xyz@idp", "idp": "64ef2a" } ] } Remove a VO role from a user. An administrator should be able to remove a VO role from any user. This operation updates the mapping rule for the idp and removes the rule for the identified user. URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}/member/{idp}/{user_id}` Response: Status: 204 No Content Switch VO roles for a user. This operation modifies the mapping rule for the given IdP. The new VO role must already exist as it cannot be created by this operation. URL: `PATCH /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}/member/{idp}/{user_id}` Request: { "new_VO_role_id: "125adf" } Response: Status: 200 OK List VO role membership user requests. This operation lists the outstanding user requests to join a VO role, when non-automatic enrolment has been configured. URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/requests` Response: Status: 200 OK { "VO_requests": [ { "id": "85efa3", "idp": "231eeb", "VO_name": "keystone-dev", "VO_role": "member", "user_id": "abc@idp" }, { "id": "99fab5", "idp": "231eeb", "VO_name": "keystone-dev", "VO_role": "admin", "user_id": "efg@idp" } ] } Approve VO role membership user request. This operation removes the request from the User Requests table, and calls PUT /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/member URL: `HEAD /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/requests/{VO_request_id}` Response: Status: 200 OK Delete VO role membership request. This operation removes the request from the User Requests table and performs no further action. URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/requests/{VO_request_id}` Response: Status: 204 No Content List blacklisted users. Users will become blacklisted if they make too many wrong attempts at joining a VO role in a domain (e.g. by quoting the wrong password/PIN). The allowed number of wrong requests is a configuration parameter. Once blacklisted, all further attempts by this user to join any VO role in this domain will fail. The domain administrator must remove the user from the blacklist before he or she will to be able to join any VO role in this domain again. URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/VO_name/blacklist` URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_name_id}/blacklist` Response: { "VO_blacklist": "VO_name": "Keystone" [ { "id": "34cb2d", "user_id": "badman@idp", "idp": "64ef2a" }, { "id": "bf21a9", "user_id": "foo@idp", "idp": "64ef2a" } ] } Delete blacklist entry URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/VO_name/blacklist/{VO_blacklist_id}` Response: Status: 204 No Content User API -------- Join DS Role. Users may join a VO role by providing the name of the domain, VO role and the PIN. The response should contain a status message which can be: 1. success - the user successfully registered as a VO role member and can begin accessing the appropriate resources immediately. 2. pending - the user has registered for VO role membership but his request must be approved by the domain administrator before he can access any resources. 3. an error message if the join request has failed. URL: `PUT /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/members` Request: { "VO_request" : { "pin": "1234", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" } } Response: Status: 201 Created { "VO_role": { "id": "85efa3", "status": "pending", "VO_name": "keystone", "VO_role": "developer" } } Check VO Role Membership Users can check the status of a join request to a specific VO role. The HTTP code indicates the status: 1. 200 indicates that the user belongs to the VO role 2. 202 indicates that the user has made a request which has not yet been approved. 3. 404 indicates that the user has not requested membership, or that the request has been denied. URL: `HEAD /OS-FEDERATION/(VO_role)/{VO_name}` URL: `HEAD /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}` Response: Status: 200 OK Resign from a VO Role. Users can resign from a VO role once authenticated, by simply quoting the VO name and VO role URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/VO_roles/{VO_role_id}` URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATION/{VO_role}/{VO_name}` Response: Status: 204 No Content Security Impact --------------- Groups will have a secret associated with them. Anyone who learns this secret may be able to join the group without the administrator knowing about it. This is mitigated by setting "automatic_join" to false so that the administrator has to accept each membership request. Nevertheless if the administrator is careless he could let the wrong user join a group. Alternatively if the group membership is very large, the administrator may find it very difficult to differentiate between genuine members and fraudsters. This could be mitigated by creating different passwords/PINs per user, or by not using this self registration functionality. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- Users have the ability to determine if they want to join a particular role or not, and can automatically resign from a role whenever they want to. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- This can ease the administrative burden of managing the privileges of federated users. Developer Impact ---------------- None. This is a self contained feature. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Ioram Sette Launchpad ID: iss-d Other contributors: David Chadwick Launchpad ID: d-w-chadwick Work Items ---------- * Implement the API * Modify Horizon Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests for the new API. Documentation Impact ==================== The federated extension docs should be extended to include a description and usage instructions for self management of VO role (PIN protected groups). References ========== Blueprint `bp self-management-roles <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/vo-roles>`_

commit_message:
Trusted Attributes Policy for External Identity Providers

Proposes a feature to add fine grained control over which
attributes (both types and values) Keystone will accept as
trustworthy from an external identity provider. All attributes
(types and/or values) that are not trusted should be
discarded by federated Keystone.

Change-Id: I4d2b1a3aa8bbb3cd8d3c76e8ec4c2b6c023db0b3
Co-Authored-By: Ioram Sette <iss@cin.ufpe.br>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/93/138693/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Trusted Attributes Issuing Policy ========================================== `bp trusted-attributes-issuing-policy <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/trusted-attribute-issuing-policy>`_ We propose that an API should be added to support control of a policy to restrict which attributes a federated Identity Provider is trusted to issue. Problem Description =================== Administrators of a federated system should be able to configure which attributes a federated identity provider can issue. For example, a bank may be trusted to issue a credit card number but not a driving license number. Currently this is controlled by the Mapping API which specifies rules for each individual Identity Provider. This means that a great deal of repetition may be required to set up rules for attribute mapping. For example, given three Identity Providers: IDPA, IDPB and IDPC, and three attributes: X, Y and Z which map into different groups: group1, group2 and group3 respectively, and say that IDPA issues X and Y, IDPB issues X and Z and IDPC issues Y and Z, then we would currently have the following mapping rules: For IDPA, X maps to group1 and Y maps to group2 For IDPB, X maps to group1 and Z maps to group3 For IDPC, Y maps to group2 and Z maps to group3 In the current system, each mapping rule must be applied twice (once each for the two IdPs). Not only that, but because mapping rules can be based on regular expression matching, then there is no guarantee that only the attribute(s) that the administrator wanted to match, will be matched. Several others may match as well. This is because the regular expression is matching on a potentially infinite set of attributes that an IdP can send. By having a trusted attributes policy, we limit the set of attributes that can be matched to only the trusted attributes as the untrusted ones will have been discarded before the mapping rules are evaluated. Proposed Change =============== We propose that the federated trust management of external IdPs be enriched to include a policy which restricts which attributes types and/or values will be accepted from each IdP. Any attributes which are not allowed by the policy will be discarded. This way, after the trusted attribute policy filtering has taken place, all of the remaining attributes can be considered trusted and the mapping rules can be applied. If this feature is added then the Trusted Attributes Policy for the example above would be: IDPA is trusted to issue attributes X and Y IDPB is trusted to issue attributes X and Z IDPC is trusted to issue attributes Y and Z and the mapping rules would be simplified to just one mapping rule: X maps to group1 Y maps to group2 Z maps to group3 that can be shared by all IdPs. Alternatives ------------ We could also simplify the mapping rules, so that we do not need to assign them to IdPs, but let them be applicable to all IdPs. Data Model Impact ----------------- This would require a new data object "Trusted Attribute Policy" which would consist of an ID, and Identity Provider ID, and a list of key-value pairs consisting of a type and a list of values. An empty list should denote any value. The federated extension migration script should be modified to create the new data structure required. REST API Impact --------------- Get an Identity Provider's set of trusted attributes: This should return a dictionary containing a list of trusted attributes, each trusted attribute should contain a type and a list of 0-* values where length 0 means any value is accepted. URL: `GET /OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/{idp_id}/trusted_attributes` Response: Status: 200 OK { "trusted_attributes": [ { "type": "email", "values": [] }, { "type": "orgPersonType", "values": ["staff", "contractor", "guest"] }, { "type": "uid", "values": [] } ], "links": { "identity_provider": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/ACME", "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/7e23a6/trusted_attributes" } } Create an Identity Provider's Trusted Attributes Policy: Populate the policy for the specified Identity Provider with the given values. URL: `PUT /OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/{idp_id}/trusted_attributes` Request: { "trusted_attributes": [ { "type": "email", "values": [] }, { "type": "orgPersonType", "values": ["staff", "contractor", "guest"] }, { "type": "uid", "values": [] } ] } Response: Status: 201 Created { "trusted_attributes": [ { "type": "email", "values": [] }, { "type": "orgPersonType", "values": ["staff", "contractor", "guest"] }, { "type": "uid", "values": [] } ], "links": { "identity_provider": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/ACME", "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/7e23a6/trusted_attributes" } } ..Update an Identity Provider's Trusted Attributes Policy: This should replace the old policy with the contents of the policy contained in the request body. URL: `PATCH /OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/{idp_id}/trusted_attributes` Request: { "trusted_attributes": [ { "type": "email", "values": [] }, { "type": "orgPersonType", "values": ["contractor", "guest"] }, { "type": "uid", "values": [] } ] } Response: Status: 200 OK { "trusted_attributes": [ { "type": "email", "values": [] }, { "type": "orgPersonType", "values": ["contractor", "guest"] }, { "type": "uid", "values": [] } ], "links": { "identity_provider": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/ACME", "self": "http://identity:35357/v3/OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/7e23a6/trusted_attributes" } } ..Delete an Identity Provider's Trusted Attributes Policy: This should empty the policy for the specified Identity Provider, effectively deauthorizing all attributes from this provider. URL: `DELETE /OS-FEDERATED/identity_providers/{idp_id}/trusted_attributes` Response: Status: 204 Deleted Security Impact --------------- The impact of this change on security would be to increase the trust level of processed attributes received in a federated authentication flow. Any attributes that are present after filtering have been specifically trusted when issued by the Identity Provider which was used for authentication. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ This may affect the performance of the federated extension authentication process as it should be called whenever a user authenticates using a federated source. However, the extent should be minimal. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- This change should be enabled when the federated extension is used. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Kristy Siu Launchpad ID: 5956 Other contributors: David Chadwick Launchpad ID: [?] Work Items ---------- * Implement Trusted Attribute Issuing Policy API Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests for the new API as well as any necessary modification to the federated extension unit tests which already exist. Documentation Impact ==================== The federated extension docs should be extended to include a description and usage instructions for configuring a trusted attributes policy for your identity providers. References ========== Slideshow describing Trusted Attributes and Simplified Mapping <http://www.slideshare.net/davidwchadwick/scalable-and-usable-attribute-mappings-in-keystone-openstack#>

commit_message:
Trigger tox from package.json, if necessary.

This patch adds several fixes to improve karma test handling.

* A postinstall hook was added to package.json, which tests for
  the existence of .venv. If it is not found, it will invoke
  tox -e py27 --notest.
* Both karma.conf files were taught to automatically detect the
  directories in which the xstatic dependencies might live, and
  pick the appropriate directory.

postinstall was chosen, because setting up a virtual environment
is likely to be useful for more than one type of npm job.

Change-Id: I822cb020bd8b2ca8d4f994b9734af5636e4bd144
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/25/188225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add support for shared volumes between guests

This blueprint proposes a change to Nova to support
attaching a cinder volume to more than one instance.

Blueprint: blueprint multi_attach_volume

Change-Id: I805c9ea757cbbe9510436cd852fed9182ff41b6f
Previously-approved: Kilo
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/04/179104/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support Cinder Volume Multi-attach ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/multi-attach-volume Currently, Cinder only allows a volume to be attached to a single host or instance. There are times when a user may want to be able to attach the same volume to multiple instances. Problem description =================== Currently, Cinder only allows a volume to be attached to one instance and or host at a time. Nova makes an assumption in a number of places that assumes the limitation of a single volume to a single instance. * cinderclient only has volume as a parameter to the detach() call. This makes the assumption that a volume is only attached once. * nova assumes that if a volume is attached, it can't be attached again. see nova/volume/cinder.py: check_attach() Use Cases --------- Allow users to share volumes between multiple guests using either read-write or read-only attachments. Clustered applications with two nodes where one is active and one is passive. Both require access to the same volume although only one accesses activly. When the active one goes down, the passive one can take over quickly and has access to the data. Project Priority ---------------- - Proposed change =============== The Changes needed in Nova are related to attach time and detach time. At attach time, nova has to remove the assumption that it can only attach a volume if it's not 'in-use'. A Cinder volume can now be attached if it's 'available' and/or 'in-use'. Cinder will only allow a volume to be attached more than once if it's 'shareable' flag is set on the volume at create time. At detach time, nova needs to pass a new parameter to the cinderclient to tell cinder which specific attachment it's requesting cinder to detach. Since a volume can be attached to an instance and/or a host, a new attachment uuid is added at detach time. Passing only an instance uuid is insufficient. The attachment_id will be optional in the cinderclient. If it isn't passed in and there are multiple attachments, then cinder will fail because it won't know which attachment to detach. By default libvirt assumes all disks are exclusive used for a single guest. If you want to share disks between instances, you need to tell libvirt when configuring the guest XML for that disk. Libvirt can reject the request to avoid problems with data consitency e.g. host level I/O caching we need to use cache=none. Alternatives ------------ The only alternative is for a user to clone a volume and attach the clone to the second instance. The downside to this is any changes to the original volume don't show up in the mounted clone. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- In the libvirt driver, the disk is given a shared SELinux label, and so that disk has no longer strong sVirt SELinux isolation. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The command line will now allow you to call nova volume-attach for a volume to multiple instances. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Any time new code is added to Nova that requires a call to detach a volume, the developer must get the volume attachment uuid for the instance. This information is embedded in the cinder volume volume_attachments list. Implementation ============== Based on the work from Walter Boring and Charlie Zhou. Agreed with Walter to start the work again. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Tobias Engelbert Work Items ---------- 1. Update the use of cinderclient to extract the new list of volume attachments when Nova fetches a volume. 2. Update all calls to cinderclient.detach() to include the attachment uuid. 3. Libvirt volume driver. Dependencies ============ * This requires a new version of the python-cinderclient. The changes in the client include the new detach API. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/python-cinderclient/+spec/multi-attach-volume * This also requires a patch in cinder to support the ability to attach to multiple instances. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/multi-attach-volume Testing ======= We'll have to add new Tempest tests to support the new Cinder volume shareable flag. The new cinder shareable flag is what allows a volume to be attached more than once or not. Have to look into a tempest test for attaching the same volume to multiple instances. Documentation Impact ==================== We will have to update the docs to discuss the new ability to attach a volume to multiple instances if the cinder shareable flag is set on a volume. References ========== * This is the cinder wiki page that discusses the approach to multi-attach https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/blueprints/multi-attach-volume

subject: User-password-update accepts blank as password
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-15 06:53:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/c027b41e7d849b27270e947caade53500de3071b', 'message': 'User-password-update accepts blank as password

Intially "keystone user-password-update username"
command worked successfully even if the user left
the new password as blank. But the issue was that
the user then was not able to log in with a blank
password and not even with his old password.

Updated the code to raise an error if the user tries

commit_message:
User-password-update accepts blank as password

Initially "keystone user-password-update username"
command worked successfully even if the user left
the new password as blank. But the issue was that
the user then was not able to log in with a blank
password and not even with his old password.

Updated the code to raise an error if the user tries
to keep his password as blank.

Closes-Bug: #1391116

Change-Id: Ie170418905930ee8449562e9eb0a6fec4553ea0c

commit_message:
Correct password parameter for glance::api

The testing keystone password was set to 'a_big_secret' throughout the
test manifest except for in the glance-api class, so the
glance-api.conf would have the wrong password and tests for
glance_image would fail. This patch sets the password to be consistent
across the manifest.

Change-Id: I8b781d3080b2dd5e894c84a23c892e4f153d8aa6

commit_message:
Switch the token provider to use strict_abc

This will ensure strict Abstract Meta Classes when extending or inheriting the
BaseProvider from the token provider API.

partially implements bp token-provider-cleanup

Change-Id: I9e02bffb42bcb8fdf059d2ca35c0d5efdd154b03

commit_message:
Bring Redhat support to acceptance tests

OpenStack Infra has jobs to run this on both Ubuntu Trusty and CentOS7.

* Add minitest to Gemfile (dependency to run beaker on centos - see 11
  http://projects.theforeman.org/issues/2650 for details)
* separate nodepool files to have trusty & centos7 support in OS infra
* class_spec: add case for repo configuration and support
  RH systems.
* don't install rabbitmq module that is not used (yet)
* install the apt module explicitly since it's no longer installed
  implicitly by the rabbitmq module

Change-Id: I17a571c8d56d55337ee0c8491fb4aad272074cf6
Closes-bug: #1444736

commit_message:
fixed behavior for rabbit_hosts variable

We identified an issue where if a user had previously defined rabbit_host,
then went to rabbit_hosts, the old value would cause confusion in many
of the OpenStack tools. This patch ensures that when rabbit_hosts is
defined, rabbit_host is absent, to avoid any configuration problems.

Change-Id: I8b5c497d2bb4f3e637aff0dd7cf61f91f173027c
(cherry picked from commit b038d2350d55e98d1df3a0957ab75919c47d6a42)

commit_message:
crontab: ensure nova-common is installed before

Because we create a crontab with 'nova' user, we need to ensure it
exists. So we need to make sure Nova is installed (common package).

Otherwise, it can lead to dependencies issues.

Change-Id: I5157e710e4f2e95c4ec9c1f45b414e4a3dbf9228
(cherry picked from commit 54802658adb87719ff5be7f8856e1da9cf5e4144)

commit_message:
Add documentations for VXLAN Tunnels

The VXLAN type driver is currently supported, this patch add
description and links for more information to the user.

Change-Id: Idb221ca4cce1a3a27bebe5ae6fc1e6ab5d030836
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/189270/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ovs-neutron-agent can be configured to use different networking technologies to create tenant isolation. These technologies are implemented as ML2 type drivers which are used in conjunction with the OpenVSwitch mechanism driver VXLAN Tunnels ------------- VXLAN is an overlay technology which encapsulates MAC frames at layer 2 into a UDP header. More information can be found in `The VXLAN wiki page. <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Extensible_LAN>`_ STT Tunnels ----------- Stateless Transport Tunneling (STT) is an encapsulation based on TCP (Unlike VXLAN/GRE which are UDP based). STT was designed to take advantage of modern NIC TCP Segmentation Offload capabilities to achieve better tunneling performance. More information can be found in `This document. <https://tools.ietf.org/pdf/draft-davie-stt-06.pdf>`_ Geneve Tunnels -------------- Geneve is the newest protocol out of this list, it is important to note that currently it is only supported in newer kernels. Geneve uses UDP as its transport protocol and is dynamic in size using extensible option headers. More information can be found in the `Geneve RFC document. <https://tools.ietf.org/pdf/draft-gross-geneve-02.pdf>`_
deleted_lines: ovs-neutron-agent can be configured to use two different networking technologies to create tenant isolation, either GRE tunnels or VLAN tags.

commit_message:
Testing guidelines

A guide to the history of testing in OpenStack, things we've learned,
and philosophy moving forward to provide a more stable OpenStack
experience for all users of all projects.

Change-Id: I7a3663a93e9ea0c9adfb443221c2025edb331644
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs refs/changes/53/150653/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. ================================== OpenStack Theory of Testing ================================== The following is an attempt to provide a "theory of testing" to be used in OpenStack projects. It accumulates what we've learned over the past few years of the OpenStack project in various iterations of automated testing. It also attempts to provide guidance for projects setting up testing in the future. ============================================= Things we've learned - usually the hard way ============================================= 1. If it's not tested, it's probably broken Time and time again when we've merged functionality that didn't have reasonable testing, it turned out that it didn't work when deployed. Live migration, Cells, and AWS interfaces are often broken in Nova. This is because of little to no testing on them. Most projects broke the first time they were hit with multiple API requests at the same time on the same API end point. 2. It is important to be skeptical of passing tests Because you wrote a test case, and it passes, doesn't mean anything is working correctly. In the past configuration changes have happened that made test scenarios run in ways that were unexpected, and no longer testing what we believed they were. This has happened with PostgreSQL and Cells in the past. It will happen with other things in the futue. Working tests should always have a documented way to show that they correctly fail when something is wrong. 3. The value of a Testing scenario is: when it breaks you know why Tests that always pass are uninteresting. They demonstrate that certain parts of the code are highly unlikely to be broken because they are too stable or too uninteresting to see changes. Tests that fail, especially on initial patch submission, are very interesting because these are preventing people from changing something. Tests that fail, but don't provide a reasonable set of bread crumbs to debug aren't very helpful. They demonstrate long standing issues that we can't fix. This can often come from having too many moving parts, and not enough isolation on the scenarios being tested. 4. Co-gating and the heavy reliance on Tempest jobs makes the system fragile Fixing problems becomes much harder when the potential bug can be in any of a large number of source trees, all with different review teams, review throughput, and cultures. These sorts of situations lead to lockups in the gate, and a fealing of powerlessness from team members. If the Neutron team can't merge bug fixes because of a bug in another repository, the team gets frustrated and gives up. If the Nova team's unit tests get broken by an Oslo library release, the team is frustrated and productivity goes way down. 5. Test results in a complex system aren't binary, they are statistical Because we have shared global state in OpenStack services, interactions between tests are possible. Some times these are test bugs, some times this is the consequence of a complex system that has global state. This means failure or success is not binary. It's statisically significant. A failed test does not mean the code that was tested was at fault for the failure. It also means that the emergence of a new catostrophic break takes time to see. 1 test failure is not useful. Many test failures becomes useful. False negatives are dangerous. They are dangerous in the same way that extra ERRORs in logs are dangerous, as they remove trust in the system, and make people ignore real errors. Proposed Test Philosophy ======================== 1. Test in a pyramid Tests should start at the lowest possible level and guaruntee interfaces and behavior. This establishes a contract, which should carry to the next level. For instance, Nova has a database API. We should test the database API against a variety of backends. Any tests above the DB API (like the Object or REST API) should assume db API backends are now tested and only one database is used in higher level tests. 2. Test components in minimum linked sets Projects that can run on their own, should be tested on their own. Projects that are tightly coupled (such as the compute kernel) can be cogated on each other. Projects that rely on the compute kernel should assume it is functioning correctly, and test above it. 3. Do not intentionally perform secondary testing OpenStack client libraries are not currently directly tested, they are only tested by secondary interaction (a nova boot triggers neutron client calls, for instance). This violates the ability to isolate failures or know whether or not those clients work in the general case. 4. Treat substantial false negatives at critical bugs False negatives make people ignore the system, and rage quit. Addressing false negatives should be a high priority issue. If a test for a feature can't be made reliable we shouldn't keep self inflicting damage on ourselves. Proposed changes ================ Co-gating units --------------- Adjust the Tempest testing and co-gating of projects in the following way: 1. Keystone - runs only keystone - runs only indentity tempest tests 2. Swift - runs only swift + keystone - runs only swift tempest tests 3. Compute Kernel (Glance, Nova, Cinder, Neutron) - assumes Keystone works, uses keystone master - use Filesystem backend for Glance - uses only mysql backend - runs only keystone + glance + nova + cinder + neutron - co-gates on image, block, compute, network tests - (until nova-network is deprecated there remains an n-net job) 4. Ironic - runs only ironic + keystone - runs only ironic tests 5. All additional OpenStack projects - runs minimum viable OpenStack stack below them (possibly service + keystone, or service + compute kernel) - assume services outside your project work correctly for the purposes of the tests - only runs tests specific to their project 6. Allow for possible voluntary project co-gating - a set of projects can decide they must be coupled together - you can only be part of one coupling (to prevent transient coupling) A bug in a project that is surfaced by another project (i.e. a Nova bug that breaks Heat) should be considered a high priority bug by both teams. The fix and associated test case should only be done in the consumed project (in this case Nova). Prereqs: None This decoupling should be able to happen without substantial coverage changes in tests. Create Client Library Functional Testing ----------------------------- Client libraries should have their own functional test suites that expect to run against real end points. These should assume a working set of services. This will allow us to fully cap dependencies on stable branches and not loose test coverage. TODO: further details on what's expected Removal of Admin Tests from Tempest ----------------------------------- Tempest should only be testing the public, user facing REST API. The admin APIs should be left to internal project testing. Prereqs: projects must spin up functional tests that cover this functionality. TODO: further details on what's expected Alternatives ------------ Become goat herders Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- - Gate Break Down - sdague - Client Functional Testing - each client core team - Removal of admin tests from Tempest - TBD Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ NA History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Kilo - Introduced .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Add MidoNet plugin manifest

Define the resources to configure MidoNet plugin with Neutron. Is worth
say that, since MidoNet plugin is not in official repos, this manifest
does not install the packages and delegates to an orchestration tool or
a wrapper manifest to do so.

Is is planned to add package declaration after Kilo release.

Change-Id: Ib5f73729f314a40197b4d1c75ec33fd246df83d9
(cherry picked from commit 5e034e2af7ecb31cfcb758c7f43f47e46ce5677a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/92/187392/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'spec_helper' describe 'neutron::plugins::midonet' do let :pre_condition do "class { 'neutron::server': auth_password => 'password' } class { 'neutron': rabbit_password => 'passw0rd' } package { 'python-neutron-plugin-midonet': }" end let :default_params do { :midonet_api_ip => '127.0.0.1', :midonet_api_port => '8080', :keystone_username => 'neutron', :keystone_password => 'test_midonet', :keystone_tenant => 'services' } end shared_examples_for 'neutron midonet plugin' do let :params do {} end before do params.merge!(default_params) end it 'should create plugin symbolic link' do is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/neutron/plugin.ini').with( :ensure => 'link', :target => '/etc/neutron/plugins/midonet/midonet.ini', :require => 'Package[python-neutron-plugin-midonet]') end it 'should perform default configuration of' do midonet_uri = "http://" + params[:midonet_api_ip] + ":" + params[:midonet_api_port] + "/midonet-api"; is_expected.to contain_neutron_plugin_midonet('MIDONET/midonet_uri').with_value(midonet_uri) is_expected.to contain_neutron_plugin_midonet('MIDONET/username').with_value(params[:keystone_username]) is_expected.to contain_neutron_plugin_midonet('MIDONET/password').with_value(params[:keystone_password]) is_expected.to contain_neutron_plugin_midonet('MIDONET/project_id').with_value(params[:keystone_tenant]) end end context 'on Debian platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'Debian'} end it 'configures /etc/default/neutron-server' do is_expected.to contain_file_line('/etc/default/neutron-server:NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONFIG').with( :path => '/etc/default/neutron-server', :match => '^NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONFIG=(.*)$', :line => 'NEUTRON_PLUGIN_CONFIG=/etc/neutron/plugins/midonet/midonet.ini', :require => ['Package[neutron-server]', 'Package[python-neutron-plugin-midonet]'], :notify => 'Service[neutron-server]' ) end it_configures 'neutron midonet plugin' end context 'on RedHat platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat'} end it_configures 'neutron midonet plugin' end end

commit_message:
Added parameters for availability zones configuration

For configuration availability zones for nova-compute
the corresponding options have been added.
For details see table Table 2.16 in
http://docs.openstack.org/juno/config-reference/content/list-of-compute-config-options.html

Change-Id: I284ebd9db3b5b7c5e9218621b516cf045e5d1375
(cherry picked from commit 47a029ced063292bd9a088e93b3a69b7a1185110)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/96/187396/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'configures availability zones' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/default_availability_zone').with_value('nova') should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/internal_service_availability_zone').with_value('internal') end { :enabled => true, :ensure_package => '2012.1-2', :vncproxy_host => '127.0.0.1', :network_device_mtu => 9999, :force_raw_images => false, :reserved_host_memory => '0', :compute_manager => 'ironic.nova.compute.manager.ClusteredComputeManager', :pci_passthrough => "[{\"vendor_id\":\"8086\",\"product_id\":\"0126\"},{\"vendor_id\":\"9096\",\"product_id\":\"1520\",\"physical_network\":\"physnet1\"}]" :default_availability_zone => 'az1', :default_schedule_zone => 'az2', :internal_service_availability_zone => 'az_int1', it 'configures availability zones' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/default_availability_zone').with_value('az1') should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/default_schedule_zone').with_value('az2') should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/internal_service_availability_zone').with_value('az_int1') end

commit_message:
wip: in tree add of EnhancedFakeLogger

For nova functional tests we need to make our logs look like
production logs, including the context information. Both to keep track
of the contexts in question, as well as to see when requests are
processing in parallel.

There is an upstream pull request to put this into fixtures proper:
https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/pull/5 however until that
lands it would be nice to move forward on local testing.

Change-Id: I4e28595821cd14e6728068b434c72940e9e56e21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/165601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from fixtures._fixtures.streams import StringStreamimport oslo_logimport testtools.compatclass EnhancedFakeLogger(fixtures.Fixture): """Replace a logger and capture its output. This is copy/paste of this out of Fixtures until the following is merged upstream: https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/pull/5. This is needed to let us see that enough information is provided for certain log messages. """ def __init__(self, name="", level=std_logging.INFO, format=None, datefmt=None, nuke_handlers=True, formatter=None): """Create a FakeLogger fixture. :param name: The name of the logger to replace. Defaults to "". :param level: The log level to set, defaults to INFO. :param format: Logging format to use. Defaults to capturing supplied messages verbatim. :param datefmt: Logging date format to use. Mirrors the datefmt used in python loggging. :param nuke_handlers: If True remove all existing handles (prevents existing messages going to e.g. stdout). Defaults to True. Example: def test_log(self) fixture = self.useFixture(LoggerFixture()) logging.info('message') self.assertEqual('message', fixture.output) """ super(EnhancedFakeLogger, self).__init__() self._name = name self._level = level self._format = format self._datefmt = datefmt self._nuke_handlers = nuke_handlers self._formatter = formatter def setUp(self): super(EnhancedFakeLogger, self).setUp() name = testtools.compat._u("pythonlogging:'%s'") % self._name output = self.useFixture(StringStream(name)).stream self._output = output handler = std_logging.StreamHandler(output) if self._format: if self._formatter: handler.setFormatter( self._formatter(self._format, self._datefmt)) else: handler.setFormatter( std_logging.Formatter(self._format, self._datefmt)) self.useFixture( fixtures.LogHandler(handler, name=self._name, level=self._level, nuke_handlers=self._nuke_handlers)) @property def output(self): self._output.seek(0) return self._output.read() # set log formatting to oslo_log fs = ('%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(process)d %(levelname)s ' '%(name)s [%(request_id)s %(user_identity)s] ' '%(instance)s%(message)s') datefmt = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" EnhancedFakeLogger( format=fs, datefmt=datefmt, level=None, formatter=oslo_log.formatters.ContextFormatter)) self.useFixture(fixtures.LogHandler( handler, nuke_handlers=False))

commit_message:
Modify the policy file

Modify the policy in etc/policy.json to a new one that provide the cloud
administrator with more roles for better control.

Change-Id: Ice6766f6cfaec2d0f94baee5cf93a463c9bea2d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/08/135408/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============= Modify Policy ============= `bp modify_policy <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/modify_policy>`_ We are proposing a change to the default policy used in the Openstack projects. Problem Description =================== The current policy file has low granularity regarding the role admin and has unclear roles regarding members. We would like admin roles for parts of the cloud, a role to manage the cloud, another to manage domains and another one to manage projects. Also we would like to provide only one role for common member, instead of the ones is used today: _member_ and Member; Proposed Change =============== Regarding the roles _member_ and Member, are not clear which one should be used for a common user of the cloud, we would like to provide only the role project_member to common users; The role admin is too general, we would like to give more options for the administrator: * cloud_admin is the role to users that need to manage the cloud, they can perform actions such as CRUD of domains, roles, hypervisors; * domain_admin is the role for admin users in domain context, they can only perform actions regarding domain, like, update the domain information s/he are associated to, CRUD of projects, users; * project_admin is the role for users that need to manage projects, they can't do operations like create users or create projects but are able to update the project information s/he are associate to, associate and dissociate users with roles in the project; * project_member is the role for common members with no admin permissions at all; Alternatives ------------ The cloud administrator can associate the role admin for every user that needs to perform any admin operation. For a user who needs to create projects, the role admin could be associate, but this is undesirable since the user with role admin can perform any operation s/he wants, including deleting domains, hypervisors and delete users; Security Impact --------------- We may have some hard coded checks that expects that the user has the role admin instead of the role defined in the policy rule. Also, as we are giving the Project_Admin permission to assign users to his/her project with determined role, a Project_Admin could grants a user the role Cloud_Admin, to avoid this we are defining the rule in Keystone that the cloud_admin needs to be associated with the domain cloud_admin_domain (We are following the same approach as keystone.v3cloudsample.json). The problem of this solution is that others services regarding Keystone don't have the information of domain in their context. We are investigating an approach to avoid that. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The roles provided need to be added to the OpenStack instantiation: cloud_admin, domain_admin, project_admin and project_member. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Andre Aranha <afaranha@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (afaranha) Other contributors: Gabriel Assis Bezerra <gabrielb@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (gabriel-bezerra) Henrique Truta <henrique@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (htruta) Raildo Mascena de Sousa Filho <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (raildo) Rodrigo Duarte <rodrigods@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (rodrigods) Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz <samuel@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (samuelms) Telles Mota Vidal Nbrega <tellesmvn@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (tellesnobrega) Thiago Paiva Brito <thiagop@lsd.ufcg.edu.br> (thiagop) Work Items ---------- 1. Create the policies for: * Cinder; * Glance; * Keystone; * Neutron; * Nova; 2. Fix the tests to pass in the new policies rules; 3. Modify Opentack to create the user admin as cloud_admin instead of admin; Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== A documentation will be provided to explain how does the policy works, what is the cloud_admin, the domain_admin, the project_admin and the project_member, what capabilities each one has, and how they are related. References ========== Github for sample policies project with tests: * https://github.com/andre-lsd/sample-policies-for-openstack

commit_message:
Use ConfigFilter for auth_token options

ConfigFilter provides a way to isolate your config options so that they
are protected from other code accessing those options. This will stop
people from relying upon our deprecated options.

ConfigFilter is available since oslo.config 1.4.0.0a2

Change-Id: Ib5b5f0d1bc4be90ff1883080ce38ce7ce601c547

commit_message:
Add $notification_driver parameter to notify::rabbitmq

It makes possible to control the value of notification_driver setting and defaults
to 'messaging' to maintain backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I3f2c29adbfb605ef288962f72ba81c11811cb357
(cherry picked from commit 9be4c24d98176304a823d14817b74faef02310f4)

commit_message:
Fix Keystone domain class

Currently ::heat::keystone::domain works only if keystonerc_admin
is sourced because of missing OS_TENANT_NAME env given to script
heat-keystone-setup-domain. This patch fixes this issue.

Change-Id: Idf5d35df2c39fe724350a00437b76be3333194c2
(cherry picked from commit c280fa550114744adb0b572982c0820ace9b207b)

commit_message:
Remove deprecated group name of option

Option detach_volume_timeout was replaced to timeouts section
in Kilo release. Now we can remove deprecated group name for that
option.

commit_message:
Separate app object and router object

Currently global 'app' object is based on Backbone.Router and
tightly coupled with it.

Related to blueprint react-router

Change-Id: Ib4575687bbc17e2515132db453648cbf24c46f17

commit_message:
Making policy namespaces more unique

This adds "data-processing:" to the beginning of all namespaces for
sahara's policy based actions. This will help ensure that we minimize
the possibility for name collisions in unified policy files.

* change policy names in policy.json
* change policy names in v10 and v11 api functions
* change policy tests to reflect newer names (not strictly necessary but
  added for consistency)

Change-Id: Ieef8c8de25764197a2ed59ba9f71c37fc62a75ca
Closes-Bug: 1460196
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/07/186907/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Move cluster deletion to common engine module

Suppose we have following scenario. I created cluster with
direct engine, after that I switched to Heat engine and removed
cluster. After that, cluster will be removed from Sahara DB,
but instances will be alive. This patch propose to add following:
if we try to delete direct-engine-created cluster with heat engine,
we will try to delete cluster in same way, like direct engine do it.

Related blueprint: deprecate-direct-engine

Change-Id: I65e22a8090560763547960213859b54b30f37f7e

deleted_lines: from novaclient import exceptions as nova_exceptions def _delete_aa_server_group(self, cluster): if cluster.anti_affinity: server_group_name = g.generate_aa_group_name(cluster.name) client = nova.client().server_groups server_groups = client.findall(name=server_group_name) if len(server_groups) == 1: client.delete(server_groups[0].id) @poll_utils.poll_status( 'delete_instances_timeout', _("Wait for instances to be deleted"), sleep=1) def _check_deleted(self, deleted_ids, cluster, instances): if not g.check_cluster_exists(cluster): return True for instance in instances: if instance.id not in deleted_ids: if self._check_if_deleted(instance): LOG.debug("Instance {instance} is deleted".format( instance=instance.instance_name)) deleted_ids.add(instance.id) cpo.add_successful_event(instance) return len(deleted_ids) == len(instances) def _await_deleted(self, cluster, instances): """Await all instances are deleted.""" if not instances: return cpo.add_provisioning_step( cluster.id, _("Wait for instances to be deleted"), len(instances)) deleted_ids = set() self._check_deleted(deleted_ids, cluster, instances) @cpo.event_wrapper(mark_successful_on_exit=False) def _check_if_deleted(self, instance): try: nova.get_instance_info(instance) except nova_exceptions.NotFound: return True return False def _shutdown_instances(self, cluster): for node_group in cluster.node_groups: for instance in node_group.instances: self._shutdown_instance(instance) self._await_deleted(cluster, node_group.instances) self._delete_auto_security_group(node_group) def _delete_auto_security_group(self, node_group): if not node_group.auto_security_group: return if not node_group.security_groups: # node group has no security groups # nothing to delete return name = node_group.security_groups[-1] try: client = nova.client().security_groups security_group = client.get(name) if (security_group.name != g.generate_auto_security_group_name(node_group)): LOG.warning(_LW("Auto security group for node group {name} is " "not found").format(name=node_group.name)) return client.delete(name) except Exception: LOG.warning(_LW("Failed to delete security group {name}").format( name=name)) def _shutdown_instance(self, instance): ctx = context.ctx() if instance.node_group.floating_ip_pool: try: networks.delete_floating_ip(instance.instance_id) except nova_exceptions.NotFound: LOG.warning(_LW("Attempted to delete non-existent floating IP " "in pool {pool} from instance {instance}") .format(pool=instance.node_group.floating_ip_pool, instance=instance.instance_id)) try: volumes.detach_from_instance(instance) except Exception: LOG.warning(_LW("Detaching volumes from instance {id} failed") .format(id=instance.instance_id)) try: nova.client().servers.delete(instance.instance_id) except nova_exceptions.NotFound: LOG.warning(_LW("Attempted to delete non-existent instance {id}") .format(id=instance.instance_id)) conductor.instance_remove(ctx, instance)

commit_message:
Modifying Swift Paths for EDP Examples

To make things more convenient for users of the JSON EDP examples,
doc and JSON payloads have been modified to use the same tree structure
as the edp-examples themselves, allowing one upload to Swift.

Change-Id: I114a6e93cb0194eab72edb065e712b9976c6b60e

subject: Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-24 06:04:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/21319360b20ba94eaa29041065efc4f5f760bfe4', 'message': "Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed

Currently, when boot from volume, the block device allocate may timeout
, then the VM will set ERROR, but volume would be available later. And
the volume won't be deleted automatically by deleting the VM. Actually,
the volume is useless and should be removed.

This patch remove the corresponding volume when block device allocation
timeout.

Closes-Bug: #1447884

Change-Id: Ib3c915b5b5920c8289d5fc69cde4a3c485ed8600
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-28 08:47:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0862370b668f39c14a3fe3e3b636f50ce78d2685', 'message': "Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed

Currently, when boot instance from block device, user can choose three
kinds of sources: (blank, snapshot or image), and compute manager will
create an volume from one of them. But the volume may create failed or
timeout at this time, then the process of instance boot will be failed.

This result in the cleanup of instance won't cleanup the corresponding
volume, and the volume is useless at that moment.

This patch remove the corresponding volume when block device allocation
failed or timeout.

Closes-Bug: #1447884

Change-Id: Ib3c915b5b5920c8289d5fc69cde4a3c485ed8600
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-04-28 08:49:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ebe6dd2d0503e23396485ed89a7f6c4d7a1f2293', 'message': "Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed

Currently, when boot instance from block device, user can choose three
kinds of sources: (blank, snapshot or image), and block device will
create an volume from one of them. But the volume may create failed or
timeout at this time, then the process of instance boot will be failed.

This result in cleanup instance won't cleanup the corresponding volume,and the volume is useless at that moment.

This patch remove the corresponding volume when block device allocation
failed or timeout.

Closes-Bug: #1447884

Change-Id: Ib3c915b5b5920c8289d5fc69cde4a3c485ed8600
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-04-28 08:50:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c38c1af5713c7b873adff3b7d13c77583e48f796', 'message': "Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed

Currently, when boot instance from block device, user can choose three
kinds of sources: (blank, snapshot or image), and block device will
create an volume from one of them. But the volume may create failed or
timeout at this time, then the process of instance boot will be failed.

This result in cleanup instance won't cleanup the corresponding volume,
and the volume is useless at that moment.

This patch remove the corresponding volume when block device allocation
failed or timeout.

commit_message:
Remove useless volume when boot from volume failed

Currently, when boot instance from block device, user can choose three
kinds of sources: (blank, snapshot or image), and compute manager will
create a volume from one of them. But the volume creation may fail or
timeout at this time, then the process of instance boot will fail.

During cleanup, the failed volume cannot be deleted, and becomes unusable.

This patch removes the corresponding volume when block device allocation
fails or times out.

Closes-Bug: #1447884

Change-Id: Ib3c915b5b5920c8289d5fc69cde4a3c485ed8600
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/177084/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

1.0.0 are available. This implementation may function with other
hypervisors, at which point _check_use_live_snapshots can be

At a high level, the process is as follows. First we create a

commit_message:
Libvirt: Add support for live snapshots

blueprint libvirt-live-snapshots

Implements support for live snapshots when QEMU 1.3 and Libvirt
1.0.0 are available. This implementation may function with other
hypervisors, at which point _check_use_live_snapshots can be
adjusted accordingly.

At a high level, the process is as follows. First we create a
destination file for the snapshot. This file uses the same backing
file as the origin disk and is of the same virtual size. We do this
since the combination of blockRebase and "shallow" copies are the
only bug-free method available as of QEMU 1.3 (Vish has submitted
patches upstream). This process ultimately produces a CoW file,
representing only the current delta between the root disk and
backing file. The final step converts the CoW delta to a backless
image matching the format of the origin disk.

Flags: DocImpact
Change-Id: Icba53336556295722c3f8b7345e6cd09d8ccfed9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/45/20545/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time cfg.BoolOpt('libvirt_livesnapshot', default=True, help='Perform snapshots without temporarily suspending the' ' instance. Requires QEMU 1.3 and Livirt 1.0 or newer.'), cfg.IntOpt('libvirt_livesnapshot_bandwidth', default=0, help='The maximum bandwidth (in MiB/s) that will be used when' ' copying the snapshot image'), # NOTE(rmk): We cannot perform live snapshots when a managedSave # file is present, so we will use the cold/legacy method # for instances which are shutdown. if CONF.libvirt_livesnapshot and not state == power_state.SHUTDOWN: live_snapshot = True else: live_snapshot = False if CONF.libvirt_type != 'lxc' and not live_snapshot: if live_snapshot: LOG.info(_("Beginning live snapshot process"), instance=instance) else: LOG.info(_("Beginning cold snapshot process"), instance=instance) snapshot = self.image_backend.snapshot(disk_path, snapshot_name, image_type=source_format) snapshot.create() if live_snapshot: # NOTE (rmk): libvirt needs to be able to write to the # temp directory, which is owned nova. utils.execute('chmod', '777', tmpdir, run_as_root=True) self._live_snapshot(virt_dom, disk_path, out_path) else: snapshot.extract(out_path, image_format) finally: if not live_snapshot: snapshot.delete() if CONF.libvirt_type != 'lxc' and not live_snapshot: LOG.info(_("Snapshot extracted, beginning image upload"), instance=instance) LOG.info(_("Snapshot image upload complete"), instance=instance) def _live_snapshot(self, domain, disk_path, out_path): """ Snapshot an instance without downtime. """ # Save a copy of the domain's running XML file xml = domain.XMLDesc(0) # Abort is an idempotent operation, so make sure any block # jobs which may have failed are ended. try: domain.blockJobAbort(disk_path, 0) except: pass def _wait_for_block_job(domain, disk_path): status = domain.blockJobInfo(disk_path, 0) try: cur = status.get('cur', 0) end = status.get('end', 0) except: return False if cur == end and cur != 0 and end != 0: return False else: return True try: # NOTE (rmk): blockRebase cannot be executed on persistent # domains, so we need to temporarily undefine it. # If any part of this block fails, the domain is # re-defined via finish. if domain.isPersistent(): domain.undefine() bandwidth = CONF.libvirt_livesnapshot_bandwidth # NOTE (rmk): Establish a temporary mirror of our root disk and # issue an abort once we have a complete copy. domain.blockRebase(disk_path, out_path, bandwidth, libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_BLOCK_REBASE_COPY) while _wait_for_block_job(domain, disk_path): time.sleep(0.5) domain.blockJobAbort(disk_path, 0) libvirt_utils.chown(out_path, os.getuid()) finally: self._conn.defineXML(xml)

commit_message:
Add notification_driver and state_path option

This patch just add two frequently use options into manila::init.

Change-Id: I3c154c1cac66579b500628f1bbc013c32089839b
Closes-Bug: 1447880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-manila refs/changes/64/177064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*state_path*] # (optional) Directory for storing state. # Defaults to '/var/lib/manila' ## [*notification_driver*] # (optional) Driver or drivers to handle sending notifications. # Defaults to 'messaging' # $notification_driver = 'messaging', $state_path = '/var/lib/manila', 'DEFAULT/notification_driver': value => $notification_driver; 'DEFAULT/state_path': value => $state_path;

subject: rabbit: Set timeout on the underlying socket
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-06-04 20:00:24.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/commit/2daf4dccc323c48ec2bc32ec59523fd3c0ec589f', 'message': "rabbit: Set timeout on the underlying socket

--
NOTE(mriedem): This is two commits squashed to address a problem with
the rabbitmq heartbeat patch in stable/kilo (since oslo.messaging 1.8.1).
--

rabbit: Remove unused stuffs from publisher

The publisher code is over engineered, it allows to override
everything, but this is never used.

None of the child Class have the same signature, sometimes
the constructor use the parameter name as the parent class but for
a different purpose, that make the code hard to read.

It's was never clear which options is passed to the queue and the
exchange at this end to kombu.

This changes removes all of that stuffs, and only use the kombu
terminology for publisher parameters.

(cherry picked from commit cca84f66d49114ce4ae85af4bbf03a14bda79121)

--------------------------------------------

rabbit: Set timeout on the underlying socket

They are some case where the underlying can be stuck
until the system socket timeout is reached, but in oslo.messaging
we very often known that is not needed to wait for ever because
the upper layer (usualy the application) expect to return after
a certain period.

So this change set the timeout on the underlying socket each we can
determine that is not needed to wait more.

Closes-bug: #1436788
Change-Id: Ie71ab8147c56eaf672585da107bec8b22af9da6c
(cherry picked from commit 77f952a1f7d87c35fb5d7eb7e052c5b9def59b22)
"}]
commit_message:
rabbit: Set timeout on the underlying socket

--
NOTE(mriedem): This is two commits squashed to address a problem with
the rabbitmq heartbeat patch in stable/kilo (since oslo.messaging 1.8.1).
--

rabbit: Remove unused stuffs from publisher

The publisher code is over engineered, it allows to override
everything, but this is never used.

None of the child Class have the same signature, sometimes
the constructor use the parameter name as the parent class but for
a different purpose, that make the code hard to read.

It's was never clear which options is passed to the queue and the
exchange at this end to kombu.

This changes removes all of that stuffs, and only use the kombu
terminology for publisher parameters.

(cherry picked from commit cca84f66d49114ce4ae85af4bbf03a14bda79121)

--------------------------------------------

rabbit: Set timeout on the underlying socket

They are some case where the underlying can be stuck
until the system socket timeout is reached, but in oslo.messaging
we very often known that is not needed to wait for ever because
the upper layer (usualy the application) expect to return after
a certain period.

So this change set the timeout on the underlying socket each we can
determine that is not needed to wait more.

Closes-bug: #1436788
Change-Id: Ie71ab8147c56eaf672585da107bec8b22af9da6c
(cherry picked from commit 77f952a1f7d87c35fb5d7eb7e052c5b9def59b22)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/63/188563/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Publisher that silently creates exchange but no queues.""" passive = False def __init__(self, conf, exchange_name, routing_key, type, durable, auto_delete): type, durable auto_delete self.queue_arguments = _get_queue_arguments(conf) self.auto_delete = auto_delete self.durable = durable type=type, exclusive=False, durable=durable, auto_delete=auto_delete, passive=self.passive) def send(self, conn, msg, timeout=None): """Send a message on an channel.""" producer = kombu.messaging.Producer(exchange=self.exchange, channel=conn.channel, routing_key=self.routing_key) headers = {} if timeout: # AMQP TTL is in milliseconds when set in the property. # Details: http://www.rabbitmq.com/ttl.html#per-message-ttl # NOTE(sileht): this amqp header doesn't exists ... LP#1444854 headers['ttl'] = timeout * 1000 # NOTE(sileht): no need to wait more, caller expects # a answer before timeout is reached transport_timeout = timeout heartbeat_timeout = conn.driver_conf.heartbeat_timeout_threshold if (conn._heartbeat_supported_and_enabled() and ( transport_timeout is None or transport_timeout > heartbeat_timeout)): # NOTE(sileht): we are supposed to send heartbeat every # heartbeat_timeout, no need to wait more otherwise will # disconnect us, so raise timeout earlier ourself transport_timeout = heartbeat_timeout with conn._transport_socket_timeout(transport_timeout): producer.publish(msg, headers=headers) class DeclareQueuePublisher(Publisher): """Publisher that declares a default queue When the exchange is missing instead of silently creating an exchange not binded to a queue, this publisher creates a default queue named with the routing_key. This is mainly used to not miss notifications in case of nobody consumes them yet. If the future consumer binds the default queue it can retrieve missing messages. """ # FIXME(sileht): The side effect of this is that we declare again and # again the same queue, and generate a lot of useless rabbit traffic. # https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.messaging/+bug/1437902 def send(self, conn, msg, timeout=None): queue = kombu.entity.Queue( channel=conn.channel, exchange=self.exchange, durable=self.durable, auto_delete=self.auto_delete, name=self.routing_key, routing_key=self.routing_key, queue_arguments=self.queue_arguments) super(DeclareQueuePublisher, self).send( conn, msg, timeout) class RetryOnMissingExchangePublisher(Publisher): """Publisher that retry during 60 seconds if the exchange is missing.""" passive = True def send(self, conn, msg, timeout=None): # TODO(sileht): # * use timeout parameter when available # * use rpc_timeout if not instead of hardcoded 60 # * use @retrying timer = rpc_common.DecayingTimer(duration=60) timer.start() while True: try: super(RetryOnMissingExchangePublisher, self).send(conn, msg, timeout) return except conn.connection.channel_errors as exc: # NOTE(noelbk/sileht): # If rabbit dies, the consumer can be disconnected before the # publisher sends, and if the consumer hasn't declared the # queue, the publisher's will send a message to an exchange # that's not bound to a queue, and the message wll be lost. # So we set passive=True to the publisher exchange and catch # the 404 kombu ChannelError and retry until the exchange # appears if exc.code == 404 and timer.check_return() > 0: LOG.info(_LI("The exchange %(exchange)s to send to " "%(routing_key)s doesn't exist yet, " "retrying...") % { 'exchange': self.exchange, 'routing_key': self.routing_key}) time.sleep(1) continue raise # NOTE(sileht): value choosen according the best practice from kombu # For heatbeat, we can set a bigger timeout, and check we receive the # heartbeat packets regulary if self._heartbeat_supported_and_enabled(): self._poll_timeout = self._heartbeat_wait_timeout else: self._poll_timeout = 1 @contextlib.contextmanager def _transport_socket_timeout(self, timeout): # NOTE(sileht): they are some case where the heartbeat check # or the producer.send return only when the system socket # timeout if reach. kombu doesn't allow use to customise this # timeout so for py-amqp we tweak ourself sock = getattr(self.connection.transport, 'sock', None) if sock: orig_timeout = sock.gettimeout() sock.settimeout(timeout) yield if sock: sock.settimeout(orig_timeout) def _heartbeat_check(self): # NOTE(sileht): we are suposed to send at least one heartbeat # every heartbeat_timeout_threshold, so no need to way more with self._transport_socket_timeout( self.driver_conf.heartbeat_timeout_threshold): self.connection.heartbeat_check( rate=self.driver_conf.heartbeat_rate) self._heartbeat_check() self._heartbeat_check() def publisher_send(self, publisher, msg, timeout=None, retry=None): def _error_callback(exc): log_info = {'topic': publisher.exchange_name, 'err_str': exc} LOG.error(_("Failed to publish message to topic " "'%(topic)s': %(err_str)s"), log_info) LOG.debug('Exception', exc_info=exc) publisher.send(self, msg, timeout) self.ensure(_publish, retry=retry, error_callback=_error_callback) p = RetryOnMissingExchangePublisher(self.driver_conf, exchange_name=msg_id, routing_key=msg_id, type='direct', durable=False, auto_delete=True) self.publisher_send(p, msg) p = Publisher(self.driver_conf, exchange_name=exchange_name, routing_key=topic, type='topic', durable=self.driver_conf.amqp_durable_queues, auto_delete=self.driver_conf.amqp_auto_delete) self.publisher_send(p, msg, timeout, retry=retry) p = Publisher(self.driver_conf, exchange_name='%s_fanout' % topic, routing_key=None, type='fanout', durable=False, auto_delete=True) self.publisher_send(p, msg, retry=retry) p = DeclareQueuePublisher( self.driver_conf, exchange_name=exchange_name, routing_key=topic, type='topic', durable=self.driver_conf.amqp_durable_queues, auto_delete=self.driver_conf.amqp_auto_delete) self.publisher_send(p, msg, timeout=None, retry=retry)
